title: Billy Connolly says new symptoms of Parkinson’s disease make him drool
text:
Billy Connolly hasn’t ruled out perfroming again despite new Parkinson’s symptoms (Picture: Virgin Radio; Splash News)

Comedian Billy Connolly hasn’t ruled out performing again despite admitting the symptoms of Parkinson’s disease have stopped him touring.

The stand-up star, 76, said that despite his condition, he is getting on with it with the help of medication, but the effects of Parkinson’s has changed how he would perform.

‘[Life is] good. I’ve stopped performing because of my Parkinson’s disease and I’ve stopped touring. I may perform at some other point but I have no plans to,’ he told Chris Evans on the Virgin Radio Breakfast show.

‘And I’m quite happy taking my medicine and getting along with it. I’ve started to drool which is a new one on me.

‘This disease it gives you a new thing every now and again that you have to deal with and drooling is my latest.

‘I walk unsteadily and my hearing is going and it’s bizarre that bits of me are falling off but it’s interesting.’

Billy may not be touring any more but he is still making documentaries (Picture: ITV)

Although he would never rule out coming back to the stage, Billy admitted that his performance would be quite different to what fans are used to.

He explained: ‘It would affect my performance. I don’t think the way I used to, I don’t think at the same speed as I used to. And because I don’t need to.

‘I don’t really know if the performance bit has gone because I have to get into the performance mode to see that. I’d have to walk onto the stage and I’ve never done that.

‘And steadily more symptoms come and it’s incurable. It’s not going to end. As a matter of fact I had a Russian doctor in New York who said you realize this is an incurable disease.

‘And I said you got to get a grip of yourself, stop calling it an incurable disease say we have yet to find the cure. Give the guy a light in the tunnel. Incurable is such an awful thing to say to somebody.’

While there may be no cure for Parkinson’s, Billy says he doesn’t fear the future as his life is good, and that his wife looks after him at home, making him breakfast and plumping his pillows at night.

Billy first revealed he was being treated for the first signs of Parkinson’s disease in 2013 while undergoing minor surgery for early-stage prostate cancer, and had acknowledged he had started to forget his lines on stage.

In January 2019 he admitted that the progression of the condition may force him to retire from performing altogether.

While he has stopped touring, he has continued to make documentary TV series including Billy Connolly’s Great American Trail, following the migration of Scots through America.

The Chris Evans Virgin Radio Breakfast Show with Sky is on weekdays from 6:30am and 10am.
